justification: SLE is a multisystem autoimmune disease that can commonly present with fever, proteinuria (due to lupus nephritis), seizures (due to neuropsychiatric involvement), and autoimmune hemolysis.}, {diagnosis: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)

justification: TTP is a rare blood disorder characterized by low platelets, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and organ damage (including kidney and brain) that can manifest as fever, proteinuria, and seizures.}, {diagnosis: Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)

justification: APS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by blood clots that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, proteinuria (due to kidney involvement), seizures (due to brain clots), and autoimmune hemolysis.}, {diagnosis: Infectious endocarditis

justification: Infectious endocarditis can cause fever, proteinuria (due to immune complex deposition in the kidneys), seizures (due to brain abscesses or strokes), and autoimmune hemolysis (as a rare complication).}, {diagnosis: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

justification: DIC is a serious condition characterized by widespread blood clotting and bleeding. It can cause fever, proteinuria (due to kidney injury), seizures (due to brain bleeding), and autoimmune hemolysis (as a possible complication).}, {diagnosis: Malignancy (e.g., lymphoma)

justification: Certain cancers, like lymphoma, can present with fever, proteinuria (due to kidney involvement), seizures (due to brain metastases), and autoimmune hemolysis (as a paraneoplastic syndrome).}, {diagnosis: Drug-induced hemolytic anemia
justification: Some medications can trigger an immune response against red blood cells, leading to hemolytic anemia, fever, and rarely, seizures and kidney involvement.}, {diagnosis: Evans syndrome

justification: Evans syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia (low platelets), which can also manifest with fever and, rarely, seizures.}, {diagnosis: Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)

justification: HLH is a rare and serious immune system disorder that can cause fever, liver and spleen enlargement, cytopenias (including hemolytic anemia), and neurological symptoms like seizures.}, {diagnosis: Systemic vasculitis (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

justification: Systemic vasculitis involves inflammation of blood vessels, which can affect various organs, leading to fever, proteinuria (due to kidney involvement), seizures (due to brain involvement), and occasionally hemolytic anemia.}
